commentsCount: for example the shotgun's damage stays the same regardless of how far are you from your target ( there's damage spread so that's no slug rounds ).\n\nOverall this is a badly designed game. reviewText:
As amusing as this game could have been I am afraid it just did not manage to do more than irritate me. No options to change key bindings or even reverse mouse made it a little awkard for me, but the game itself did nothing to win me over. You just wander through fairly linear yet pointless maps killing humanoids I assume are zombies with items I assume are weapons until you get fed up and try to figure out how to quit the game.

Oddly enough quitting was the most challenging part of the game as just as I decided I had enough the game stopped responding and I had to ctrl-alt-del to the task manager.

The only thing I liked about the game was the sound track .... and for the life of me I still don't know why.

Interesting concept but not a game I would play.

reviewText:
Stolen from your home, Dead Bits plops you into a voxel world of deadly testing in a retro inspired circle strafing hell. The rules are simple: grab a gun, kill anything that moves, and try to stay alive amid the hordes running your way and the deadly traps in your path. So what's the catch? Well, pretty much everything after the first level..

Dead Bits is a simple game, which I'm perfectly fine with, but it does so very little with everything that it attempts that it's just plain boring. Enemy AI is entirely nonexistent, running toward you with the fever of a teenage girl who caught a glimpse of her favorite pop idol walking buy. This more or less devolves the game into running backwards while holding down the trigger, having to fear more about falling off the edge of the map than anything the enemies might do. The guns are dull and lack any sense of power or recoil, which makes mowing down waves of bullet sponge enemies even less interesting.

The most egregious thing about Dead Bits however is how bloody frustrating it can be, by way or deliberately inflating the difficulty for no reason but to make you angry. Instant kill obstacles that you're never made aware of abound, making for numerous deaths which feel not at all your own fault, and a complete lack of checkpoints turns the lengthier levels into absolute chores to complete. The extended death animation is particularly annoying, itself taking too long to finish and then proceeding to boot you to the level select screen so you can wait for levels to reload before trying them again. I completed the games brief 9 levels in just under 2 hours, but it only took me that long because I died at least a dozen times for cheap reasons every level.

Though it's rather simplistic, I actually did like the cel-shaded art style developer Microblast was going for with most of the game, though for whatever reason they weren't content to stick with it and instead chose to go with a completely different style for the guns and character models. The end result is a complete mess of conflicting styles and really puts to waste the great foundation they had before they added the odd pseudo realistic elements.

Dead Bits is the sort of game I'd expect to see a student or modder put out as a first step toward something more ambitious and polished. If that were the case it might be a commendable, if heavily flawed, first attempt at making a game, but as a finished retail product there is no way I could advise anyone to pick it up, which is to say nothing of wasting your time and sanity playing it. I feel there was potential here at some point, but in the end it's about as enjoyable as banging your head against a brick wall, and could very well do you just as much harm.

You can read more of my writing on Kritiqal[kritiqal.com].

reviewText:
How do I put this lightly.

-No voice acting.
-Boring story that was likely thought up in two seconds.
-Graphics that a child could make.
-I've seen jumping onto platforms done better in games LITERALLY made by children. This mechanic seems like the developer simply didn't care.
-The map design is horrible. There are holes in the floor every few feet. Good luck shooting enemies when you're falling to your death by backing up every couple seconds.
-Unlimited ammo, so forget any form of tactical shooting, spraying and praying is fully encouraged. Taking away any challenge from the actual COMBAT.
-The sounds are in the wrong places. I'm running outside and I hear the echoing as if I'm inside a cave. I enter a tunnel, and it sounds like I'm outside.
-Too short. I guess the dollar price tag COULD make that acceptable, but I pay $20 for games that get me 100+ hours of gameplay. That's a maximum of 20Â¢ per hour, this game is charging you $1 for 20 minutes worth of missions (If even that much.) That's a ripoff.
-The music is an edgy teen's dream. Instead of picking a quality soundtrack the developer kindly picked WUBWUBWUBBWAA instead. It sounds like frogs are screaming at me throughout the entire game.

Just do yourself a favor, if you get this game for free, keep it uninstalled, hide it from your library, just NEVER touch it.  Save yourself the frustration.

reviewText:
My name is Quilly.  Zombie aliens have abducted me and will probe me in my nether regions if I do not pass their tests.  Each test involves being dropped into a map with a random weapon and killing zombie aliens while trying to avoid falling off the map into oblivion.  No matter how you die, the cutscene that follows involves zombie aliens powerbanging you in a death orgy.  I pass 3 tests and am feeling pretty good about myself.  The fourth test is harder.  The zombie aliens have dogs and giant friends and they put holes all over the floor to make it easier for me to die.  I give up.  Zombie alien probes are likely more pleasureable than laboring through this game.

Zombie Alien Anoos Probe: 10/10
Game: 1/10

reviewText:
Why?
Why can I bunnyhop and won't stop jumping?
Why is there unlimited ammo?
Why are there pitfalls everywhere?
Why does the game change its pace every level?

Controls are kinda awkward, especially that bunny hopping can easily kill you. And the game needs to decide what it wants to be. Sometimes it's a shooter, sometimes a bad 3d platformer. Level design seems arbitrary to me with obvious misdesigns. Why do I have to get the bat and don't have it from the beginning? Enemy AI is non-existant. Why change the environement in level 6? Why insta-kill lava without warning? Why why why?

I honestly could not stand this game even though I played through the first five levels. Being hard is one thing, being frustrating another. Do not buy this, even for one buck. Sorry.

The soundtrack is good though. And it has cards. I don't care.

reviewText:
Dead Bits is an arcade FPS where you are apparently trying to gain your freedom by shooting things while walking backwards in between bouts of pointless platforming.

The intro level seems fine enough.  Here's a gun, shoot those guys, watch them explode in a mess of cubes.  Ok, this could be fun to mess around with.  That feeling quickly fades once you start going through the monotony of the following levels.  Enemies essentially consist of kamikaze monsters that run straight at you with reckless abandon.  They swing wildly and miss as you circle strafe around them, but the game throws a red puff on your screen indicating you've been hit anyway.  That leaves the strategy to walking backwards and killing the enemies as they filter toward you.  But wait just one second, because some levels make the ground behind you magically disappear causing you to back into your death.

And death is so much fun.  There are no checkpoints and every death kicks you back to the level select screen, because who doesn't want to reselect and reload the same level constantly?  Of course, if you like reselecting and reloading the same level you are going to love this...platforming!  Very few games do first person platforming well, and this is clearly not one of them.  One section has you jump from disorienting spinning cube to disorienting spinning cube.  Fun times.  There are also moving platforms that for some reason, even when you are standing on them, don't move you.  So you have to actually walk with the platform as it moves toward your destination.

The gunplay in this is also rather poor.  The weapons are bland and boring and pack no punch.  The smg sounds more like a typewriter than a firearm.  Occasionally a kill will trigger a slo-mo moment.  Unforunately, it's not the kind like Killing Floor that allows you to pull off a couple quick headshots, but the kind where everything just slows down around you for a couple seconds and then you carry on.  The melee weapon is a frustrating tool you are forced to use due in part to poor hit detection using it, and the aforementioned poor hit detection when enemies swipe at you.  Your best bet is to creep toward enemies slowly and stopping as soon as you pull one, since enemies only start their kamikaze attack once you reach a certain distance threshold.  But by creep I don't mean use the crouch button.  It's there and entirely pointless.

The concept of the game seems decent on the cover, but the execution leaves much to be desired and I wouldn't recommend it.  If you want to walk backwards and shoot things play Serious Sam.

reviewText:
While I did buy it for cheap, I am not gonna cut it some slack, despite winning my money back from the trading cards.

So, lemme get this out of the way - Yes, I think this game is fun.
Would I recommend it? Absolutely not.

This is a First-Person Shooter game, a relatively short one at that.
The entire game is 9 levels long, which sums up to around...30 minutes?
Longer if you suck at this game.

The game is fun, because it does not stop you from what you are supposed to do - shoot enemies.

However, the fun is killed because of these things:-Very restricted and slippery mouse movement
-Cheap enemy and platform placement
-Awkward jumping
-No map to indicate where you are in the level
-No checkpoints

That's right - if you die, you go back to the beginning of the level, no questions asked.

I do like that there is literally infinite ammo in the 2/3 weapons that you get (this game only has 3 weapons - an assault rifle, a shotgun and an...icicle?) and that makes the game fun, because you can go crazy while shooting. But what hinders everything is the really awkward and restricted mouse movement.
Player movement isn't that bad, it's the jumping that can really put you off.

You will be falling off the world a lot in this game, especially on levels 5 and 6.

The music is just...horrible. It really has horrible music.
I am the kind of guy who really hates these...wub-wub songs. And this game's full of them.

It is a nice distraction, and a fun one at times, but this game honestly is bad and I do not recommend you play it.
This game feels like an alpha version and doesn't really deserve a place on Steam.

Dead Bits gets a score of: 3.7/10.0
Good for a 10 minute distraction
date: nothing else. Recommended to stay as far away as possible.""

reviewText:
Presentation
Dead Bits is one of those games that look amazing at a first glance, just because it's different and it baits you with cool concepts, which in this case work only on paper. The game begins with a short story about how the alien which you control, Quilly was abducted by another one named Quanton while he was sleeping and forced to complete all of his tests in order to escape. From there onwards you have to complete nine distinct levels which make absolutely no sense and only get more annoying and less cool as you advance through them; as for the story perspective, scrap all that because nothing the game has to offer makes any sense in that matter, as the levels aren't even tied-in, meaning you will have to select the next one individually from a menu once you've completed one of them. While the first two levels are the closest to what the game seemed to be from its trailer and screenshots, once you get over that, it only gets more annoying and pointless as time passes and you see how stupid it can truly become.
Rating: 2.5

Gameplay
There are nine different levels, each meant to have its unique twist, starting with the first two that respect the cubic look of the environment, which is probably one of the main reasons that made anyone buy this thing, in which you will have to use the guns at your disposal to get rid of basic enemies, and continuing to the rest of the seven remaining levels which range from way worse to what the hell is this thing. While they are definitely unique in their own way, most of the levels won't even work properly as enemies will often get stuck or fail to spot you making the entire challenge feel ridiculous as you'll probably die falling through some inexplicably placed hole more often that you will by actually being defeated. On top of all that, the bugs are countless as you will often get pushed by invisible enemies off the map, jump in the wrong direction or not being able to jump at all when you should.
Rating: 1

Graphics
The cubic look of its universe is probably what attracted anyone to this title, but unfortunately it only looks like that for the first two levels, which you can complete in less than three minutes; from there onward the game tries to be unique by adding a new twist to each level, making horribly designed mazes, dark corridors that feel pointless above scary and one way alien space ship highways designed using Microsoft Paint.
Rating: 2

Audio
The sound effects are as basic as they can get, meaning that you'll probably find them in the first page of Google results under some basic sound resources website; as for the soundtrack it doesn't sound exactly horrible, but neither is it good or fitting the game in any shape or form, as it ultimately comes down to whether you like repetitive electronic/dubstep, but even if you do there are only a few songs, so you can probably just get them without having to play this abomination.
Rating: 2.5

Extras
If for god knows what reason you decide to complete this entire game, it might take you up to an hour and a half, and aside from that there is nothing else to do around since none of the levels are fun nor challenging to provide replay value and there are no achievements or leaderboards to reward you for actually putting through with this.
Rating: 1

Verdict
I honestly thought this was still part of Steam's Early Access programme since it feels unpolished, unfinished and pointless in its current stage, but that isn't the case since this game has been out for almost a year to date and there is still no reason for why someone would want to play this for more than five minutes.
Rating Overall: 1.8

Check out the full review and a lot more about Dead Bits at http://gamedragons.net/viewtopic.php?f=7&t=326

reviewText:
Pfffff finally finished this game, dayum was it kind of hard, because it is not really well made, simple mechanics, pretty repetitive gameplay over the course of the whole game.

Graphics - Well, graphics wise, if you like games like minecraft, without the survival, gameplay, music, exploration and overall feel of the game, Dead Bits is the game for you. And i would like to add, why is it so freacking shiny, boy does it tire the eyes quick. 6/10

Music - Now kudos to the Devs for getting original music by Frost Orb, and now the bad part. It is repetative, there are probably 2-3 songs in the whole game (there may be more, but that is all I heard). Ohh and the monsters you fight (zombie aliens) have only 1 sound file .. yea 4/10

Cinematics - 2 in the whole game, one for the start and one for the end. 2/10

Story - You are here, peacefull, kidnap, do this to be free, finish doing it, you are free, end. 3/10

Content - Not much, 9 levels, 3 weapons, 3 enemy variations, 3 bioms, and ... ohh wait, that is it. 2/10

Controls - Controls surprisingly good, but you can fall off ledges pretty easily, everything is slippery. 7/10

Gameplay - Well paced, having said that, you start the game knowing you have to finish the 9 levels, there is no build up through the 7 levels between the first and the last, and at the last there is the final boss. Other than that, solid shooting, don't know if having no recoil is bad or not, but hey it's good. 5/10

Well the game does things right, and there are things it does really bad. I would suggest if you want to get the game for yourself or a friend, buy it when it is on sale,

Overall Score: 4.1/10

reviewText: With the best will in the world I can't think of any reasons to recommend this game to anyone. First, it has no rebindable keys. Not that the game has that many controls but it should be in any game, regardless of the complexity of controls. You can control your character with both WASD and the arrrow keys but you are still stuck with the rest. Second, the game simply doens't have much to offer. It has 9 short levels wich it calls Tests; Test 1, Test 2 etc. First, I thought they were just tutorials but they are the actual game. Really strange difficulty spikes too. Some levels are dead easy and over in the blink of an eye, others are frustratingly hard and you keep dying over and over again. The soundtrack is a hit or miss, depending on the fact if you like dubstep or not. You can't adjust the music volume. There is only a master volume slider. One last thing, if you suffer from slight motion sickness because of very narrow FOV's, this isn't your thing either. I had to stop playing after half an hour and left it open to collect the last trading cards. OK, those cards are one little positive aspect but you aren't buying a game just for that right?\nDisclaimer: I got this game some time ago as part of a huge bundle :)

reviewText:
In Sum: More of a poorly made demo project than a game, because it's clearly not finished and too poorly made to make it worth trying.  It sucks.  0/5.

-----

The worst thing about this game is that it sometimes forgets how much it sucks.

Dead Bits is a block-based first person shooter, which might seem a novel concept.  When I fired it up after hearing all the negative, I was pleasantly surprised that it actually ran.  Comparisons to Bubsy 3D were not right.  This game actually works.  It just sucks.

The first awkwardness is the intro to the levels, where you seem frozen in midair for a few seconds before dropping into a cube.  To actually play you have to jump down to the level.  But if you don't jump down right, you will fall and die.  In fact, the challenge of the game is not so much avoiding enemies as avoiding the crappy level design.

There is a nice touch for this kind of game, but not for a hardcore FPS, in that monsters have HP over their heads.  This is the only thing that makes Level 4 bearable.  But this doesn't make killing monsters any more easy or fun.  In Half-Life I can perfectly melee attack headcrab zombies, I can do great things with a sword in L4D2, I used to have a reputation of my skills with a lightsaber in the Jedi Knight games.  But this game's baseball bat weapon is hit or miss.  I take damage and don't even know why.  Which might not be the monster's fault, as I died in a corridor in level 2 for no reason once.  Something is very off there.

Then when I play level 3, and there's a wave of zombies coming down the hall, and I have to whack them with a bat and I'm actually doing it, it's kind of satisfying.  Then the game turns gray and goes into slow-mo, and whatever timing I had is gone.  Just another poor design choice there. You see, when you kill a monster, there's a chance the game will turn gray and slow down to make it more dramatic, which unfortunately is not disimilar to what happens when you die.

The biggest problem for me, though, is that you cannot change key bindings.  Left-handed players are pretty much screwed.

I can't help but feel there's an attempt at a game in here, but it's just not there.  The level design is what kills this game, more than anything.  Fortunately, there aren't that many levels, and they aren't that long.  I only managed to get through four of them before I gave up.

reviewText:
I had fun for about 3 minutes.

Then the game started.

Serious part:

This game is god-awful. I would honestly rather play Superman 64 while somebody holds a shotgun to my jaw.

The gameplay is terrible.

You can beat the first 5 levels in under 10 minutes.

Notice how I said first 5? Yeah, after level 5 the game becomes insanely difficult.

Level 6 is a fire level where you are completly unarmed for the entire mission until you reach the end using the game's horrible jumping physics, after which you get an SMG. Shortly after, a boss spawns with easy to destroy projectiles. And then he picks up speed to the point that it's impossible to dodge. By then he's sitting on top of you because you can't look straight up. If you DO manage to beat him, you get sent to level 7.

Level 7 is the last level I played before being 100% done with this game. You get the most inaccurate laser gun I've ever seen in a video game, an then your dropped on a narrow pathway with 2 UFOs with 1000 health EACH. After killing those you get sent to a Sonic the Hedgehog esque half-pipe like the special levels from Sonic 2. And there are little spiky things that insta-kill you if you touch them, making you go aaaaall the way back to the start. AND THEY'RE ALMOST IMPOSSIBLE TO AVOID.

This game was not at all worth .14 cents.

reviewText:
This game handles very poorly.

It is extremely repetative and overall lack luster in design.


Pause, doesnt work. Yeah I know that the game doesnt call it 'pause' per say...regardless
you press the menu button and it freezes your mouse aiming. You can still strafe left and right, forward and back
and Zombies can still attack you.

Speaking of ZOMBIES, WTF!
Seriously, the game opens with you being abducted by aliens, and then suddenly: zombies...
There is an explanation to this... a very weak one mind you...

Speaking of Weak,
The First gun, the uzi, SMG thing, is a pea shooter. It is worthless. Id only recommend using it if you have no other option.

There is no ammunition, guns fire infinitely, which I think kills any depth or complexity this game may have.
and there are jarring inconsistencies with the game's design.

The most notable being the starting platform.
It's textured and I guess it is supposed to resemble water. But everything else is just blocks.
There is the particle effect that marks the end of the level which is like a steam kind of effect, which is an outlineless gradient and clashes.  The bat is a chrome textured Cylinder again, it clashes with the block style of the game.

The fonts are a minor issue, but they too do not really gel with the design style.

Convenyance is an issue.

Let me ask,

If the goal is to kill all the enemies, why cant the level just end when I kill the enemies?
That would make more sense than walking to an arbitrary spot... Ill tell ya that much.

Why is it that in level 3, I dont have to kill all the enemies, but in seemingly every other level I do?

Why is the HP indicator just a number?
I actually didnt notice any HP at all, and seeing as many FPS games go without Health guages I just assumed this was one of them.

The health packs look like red rubics cubes and do not indicate that they heal you. There isnt even a cliche white cross on it.
There isnt a pop up saying Health restored" Nothing!

Collision detection is buggy. Occasionally zombies seem to be able to hit me from quite far away.
Conversely
date: the Bat seems to be able to reach further than feels natural.\n\nTurning is a problem
recommended:
the all green zombies which run at you can get into your blind spot and because you turn so slow
they can remain out of reach indefinitely

This game shouldnt be sold
hoursPlayed:
and I say this without malice.
This is just extremely shoddy design and it isnt even comparable to many free titles you can find...

"

reviewText: Simply bad and insulting to PC gaming and it's customers.\n\nThis feels like a quick buck attempted to be made by using the current popularity of voxel design games. Dead Bits is designed with the look of games like Mincraft, but there is no building, creativity, or any practical use for the cubes. It's actually a first person shooter with waves of zombies of three sizes. There are about three or four weapons that all feel exactly the same besides the one melee baseball bat weapon. When you kill a zombie they sometimes have a Killing Floor slow-mo effect. The world is built with holes in the ground as the one challenge in the game becuase if you fall you die. It literally feels like they just took random stuff from other games and quickly slapped them together just to say here
date: there's some cool stuff in here".\n\nIn the end this entire game feels like a blatant student project being sold to help some people make a quick dollar from doing next to nothing. It takes no skill to play
recommended: has nothing new as gameplay mechanics
hoursPlayed:
and requires no thinking. I only played it for as long as I did to prove this to myself and to finish getting the cards. I won't be selling the cards since I don't believe they deserve a dime until they add some quality content to this shallow game.

This is also one of those Greenlight games that asked for votes and offered a free key once greenlit. It's a horrible practice and it needs to stop. $4.99 is highway robbery for something anyone with no game experience could tinker around and make in Minecraft or any other simple sandbox or mod. I don't see anything in this game that requied talent to create.

Also note that the forum seems to be filled with people praising this game. When a user made a topic questioning this they were banned. I posted in the topic also questioning what was good about this game and was also banned from that forum. I can't say why this is
voteText: but I have my suspicions. Either way this is my review and I didn't enjoy this game. If anyone did I'd love to know how."

reviewText: Dead $hits
voteText: 26 of 46 people (57%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Introduction
Dead Bits is a colorful first person shooter which features environments and enemies, which are made out blocks. It is about a creature named Quilly who is abducted by an alien and has to fight hoards of blocky enemies to regain his freedom.

The game features nine unique levels which all provide unique challenges. This may sound like if the game is a little bit short and it indeed is. I managed to finish everything in two hours and some people can certainly do it even faster. Although the levels lack in quantity, their quality makes up for it. Every level is very distinct from one another, so no level feels the same. Although they provide variety in challenges and difficulty, they are fairly linear, so there is no point in exploring them.

There are four weapons in this game, a submachine gun, a shotgun, a bat and an alien blaster. They come with unlimited ammunition and no reloads, but are otherwise pretty basic. Shooting is not the only thing you do in this game, though, there is also an emphasis on platforming. For the most part it handles pretty well and the levels are designed with that in mind, but sometimes the jumping can be slightly delayed and Quilly is unaffected by moving platforms so these have to be handled with caution.

The graphics are very simple by the nature of the pixelated blocks, it still looks fine though especially with added lighting effects on higher settings.
This game is accompanied by a dubstep soundtrack which cues in and out depending on level progression, and every level features one or more distinct songs.

Pros
+  Nice difficulty curve
+ Smooth and stable gameplay with no glitches
+ Pretty lighting effects
+ Very high variation in level themes
+ Large soundtrack

Cons
- Platforming can be a bit awkward
- Very short
- No pause feature
- Linear level design

Conclusion
Dead Pixels is a basic game, which does nothing new in the FPS genre, but is crafted pretty competently, so that the gameplay is still enjoyable. With the low asking price of 0.99 USD in mind this game can be recommended for someone who wants a short distraction from life.

Rating: 6.5/10

This review was submitted for Golden Raffle Group, check us out for more reviews ranging from Indie games to AAA games to F2P games.

Game key provided by Microblast Games.

reviewText:
This is a game programmed, desgined, etc. by one guy. having seen that, I'm going to change my review a little bit.

While good and simplistic in design, there are a few things about this game that are frustrating.

- when shooting  at large enemies close up, there are usually no frames of reference, causing cheap falling deaths
- the weapons are fairly ineffective
- The platforming is frustrating.
- if you die, you have to reload the level. There is no retry button, save for the last level, which restarts on it's own when you die.

There is a certain bit of trial an error in the game... The weapons are farily weak, yes. But it does add to the panic of the game... and some cheap deaths I mentioned above.

The level designs are pretty meh until you get to the 6th and 7th levels. Then they look really cool, but the platforming is still rough, 8th level is unique, 9th is a gauntlet. Be warned... the 5th level is super frustrating...

The soundtrack is awesome! I really enjoyed listening to it. Even when I was growling in frustration, the music (when it played) was entertaining and kept me somewhat involved.

This game is far from perfect. I recommend this game with a caveat: Don't come into this expecting perfect physics and amazing controls. This I see as more of an art project. Kinda neat, but not something to spend a whole lot of time on.

reviewText:
Ever since Minecraft, these cube maniacs have led to these waste of games. Don't even dare to pay 5 euros for this. You'd be better off going condomless inside an AIDS infected tranny â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥. I played 6 out of the 9 levels. I left the rest for card farming. But even with cards, I feel sorry for the 0.14 euros I paid for this. Even with the cards. This is nothing more than a browser game.

Pros: Could be better, a multiplayer would've been nice and maybe this game would've been worth any money.

Cons:
Jumping Mechanics. Press left and right mid-air? Nothing happens. Land back on the ground? Time to go left and right.
Aiming. Can't look up after a certain point. Sluggish orientation.
â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ing chiller font?!
3 year old level design
3 year old character design
Die? Same ending animation. Fall to your death in the void? Enemies surround you and eat you. Die in the lava? Enemies surround you and eat you. Explode to bits? Enemies surround you and eat you. HP reaches 0? Screen goes white.
Die? Loading screen.
Die? Back to menu.
Die? Wanna retry? Loading screen again.
9 boring, repetitive levels.
HP on top of enemies (in Chiller font, I might add).
Boring, repetitive textures and models.
Killing Floor slow mo. Because why not?! Everything else in this game is perfect. That's what it needed.
MOTHER F/U/CKING DUBSTEP SOUNDTRACK?!?!
Boring browser game. Nothing more. Nothing less. Get it for under 20 cents to get the Trading Cards and sell them. Don't even bother with the badges.

reviewText: Back when I was 9 years old my mum was diagnosed with breast cancer. She died 4 months later. I was in deep depression, Kids bullied me at school because my mom had cancer â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥" and I tried to kill myself at the age of 10. After hearing the news
date: my grandmother was looking everywhere she could to find something to make me happy again
recommended: and then she found it: Dead Bits.\n\nShe gave the game to me on my 11th birthday and I've enjoyed it ever since! It completely made me forget about my mother's tragic death and boosted my overall happiness extreme amounts. I lost my virginity at the age of 12 due to this game. It helped me out of my depression

reviewText:
This is a gameâ€¦ A really bad one at that.

Music is pretty annoying and most likely played during the development of this game. And the time it took to develop this game is equal to how long the songs were in length. I mean dubstep is still pretty popular but you shouldnâ€™t pick a gameâ€™s soundtrack based whats popular at the time.

The graphics tell me that the people who created this game lacked any means to model or texture anything besides the logos and GUI. Which also could meanâ€¦ they didnâ€™t( or donâ€™t) know how toâ€¦? They also picked a really horrible font to use, you can see the horrible font, in all its glory, in the screenshots.

There is no aesthetics in the game that made it genuine or memorable to me. Could have tried harder. Like picking a nice color palette and being a little more abstract with level design.

Lastly the gameplay, It sucked, IT REALLY SUCKED! The user interface is extremely minimal and expects the player to not play long enough to care. You also cant configure it in the menu. The enemies are extremely simple and probably only took a couple of lines to program. The enemies have health bars, the thing that sounds nice on paper but only shows me how much the programmer(s?) cared about me. I can see the arbitrary numbers they used for the enemies and feel no sense of progression because of it.

This game rolled off steam GreenLight(Thanks, Gaben!)â€¦ And the only way I could image how this game made it on steam was manufactured votes from either bots or stupid people who were probably thinking, â€œOh this game will never make it onto steamâ€¦ voted and shared!â€. Guess what. It made it to the storefront, jackasses!

If somebody bought you this game, unfriend them immediately. It might mean they don't care about you or your friendship. Otherwise if this was a joke gift, kick them in the gonads and cherish your friendship with an equally bad game gift.

Steam, please remove this awful piece of garbage from the store.

reviewText:
Received this game for free and I still feel ripped off.

Overall I wasn't expecting an intense game with amazing graphics, but I did not anticipate it being so flawed. The lack of time they spent on graphics should have been devoted to fixing any of the game's many faults that make it irritating and nearly unplayable. The laziness of the developers was most apparent when they copy and pasted so much of the scenery" that they ended up creating an indoor horizontal waterfall with no start point.

Dead Bits' pathetic attempt at creating a FPS horror game also makes it less than ideal as a cheap gift for a kid
date: I wouldn't be surprised if more effort went into the death "cutscene" than the rest of the game put together.\n\nThe only point of playing this is for the value of the Steam Cards
recommended: and even then it's a stretch.\n0/10 I want my life back."

reviewText:
So Dead Bits.

Judging from the screen shots below of Markiplier and co, Then Yeah, Thats what you can expect.

The Very First Impression this game gives you, And I mean the very first First Impression, Before the Title screen is this BLINDING White Logo of the Developer. Dev, I couldn't even see what you were trying to do with that. I don't want to be blinded by your logo before the title screen.

And then the Title screen afterwards I am welcomed to after my eyes have adjusted to that Blinding white flash is one of the most Horrendous things I have ever seen. I get that theres the undead thing with the enemies but for someone looking at your game, you have already put me off BEFORE im even Playing.

Options menu - Nothing to write home about. Fullscreen and 3 choices of picture quality.

As for the game, It runs fine enough. Controls easy to understand. Game is bad. Its horrible to play. I feel almost as blinded by it as by your own logo screen.

This mish mash of Dubby electro music 'Which feels horribly out of place' on this Ugly sight of a game just doesn't go together. and I dont feel rewarded by standing still while slashing down enemies one after the other as they come at me in an orderly fashion. Queing up for death, Thats not good.

At the end of the day, When all is said and done. This game is just one Big Headache and is just Youtube Bate. Pass.

reviewText:
Pros:
Trading cards
Soundtrack is nice

Cons:
-The enemies can be flat out ridiculous (In one of the levels the bosses can just flat out â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ing walk in mid air when you walk far from them and attack which makes it 10 times harder)
-You hear dubstep CONSTANTLY in the game (ALL the music in the soundtrack has dubstep as the genre) unless it's for some reason not playing in a level (Could be a pro if you REALLY like dubstep)
-There's a lot of glitches
-There is NO air strafing at all (If you jump and want to turn in mid air you cannot do it at ALL, even on big jumps)
-You have to watch a stupid death animation for like 7 seconds before you can skip it and you are sent to the level select screen instead of just restarting the level
-The game is pretty short but beating it takes a couple hours cause the game is such a pain in the â™¥â™¥â™¥

I beat the game and I'm never touching it again.

reviewText:
You know how slow motion tends to be used for some kind of amazing introduction for something important? Well, dead bits is too good for that and instead you get an awful slowmotion when you kill a certain amount of enemy!
Oh but wait there is more! You know how awful it is when you are in midair and move a bit to the side and fail to get on the platform? Well dead bits fixed that problem by making it impossible to control your movement when jumping!  So hop around as much as you want just remember to aim before jumping!

The game itself is amazing! I mean who doesn't like being tricked by the game when they are about to win? Like putting a wall of lava with no pior warning in front of you so you can die and repeat the whole level again?

6/10 Not enough slowmotion

reviewText:
you know how game making kits come with tutorials? you know, the ones that help you slowly put together a game using basic code and free assets? dead bits feels like a game made from some of those tutorials, which might explain why it's so awful.

bloody hell, where to start? everything that could go wrong has done so in this game. it's a game where your health is measured with a single number.
to begin with, it looks awful. bright colours thrown onto squares, and the devs claim it's pixellated". no doubt this is riding on the minecraft bandwagon
date: but if you're going to copy something popular
recommended: copy it right. at least minecraft has consistency and a colour pallet that doesn't make one want to cry.\n\nthe story is practically non-existant. a guy gets kidnapped by aliens and has to do tests. there's really nothing to say
hoursPlayed: asides from the fact that you're at least making super mario brothers jealous in terms of writing.\n\nthe gameplay is bare bones and entirely uninteresting. in my playtime i found three weapons; a shotgun
voteText: a machine gun (both of which i'm willing to bet are free assets based on how they don't look anything like the rest of the game's art style - or lack thereof)
helpfulPercent: and what i'm guessing is supposed to be a metal pipe
votesHelpful: but in reality is an untextured bar. none of them have any interesting functions

reviewText:
Three weapon types, Three monster types (Arguably three variations of the same monster). Gunplay is unsatisfying. Level design varies between awful and mildly infuriating. 'Do it again, stupid' loss states are irritating when at the end of a level which consists of nothing but jumping puzzles, 1/100th of your toe touches instakill lava and you have to start again. I've had students make more interesting and inspiring games for assignments than this.

But it has dubstep and Markiplier made a video of it which got 400,000 views: so the twelvies will buy it.

Thankfully I got my copy in a $1 bundle which I bought for other games.

It's titles like this that makes me sad that steam doesn't have a 'remove from library' option.

reviewText:
DO NOT PURCHASE THIS GAME
You have been warned.[/b]
Dead Bits has to be one of the worst games that I have ever played, I'm dead serious.

Here is a list of reasons and opinions why: You can't airstrafe AT ALL! Once you leave the ground you can not turn in the air.
The levels are called Test #. Seriously.
The hitboxes for things such as trees seem to extend way beyond the tree itself which means you sometimes bump into one of these hitboxes at random.
You have infinite ammo and even though this is my personal opinion I think most people agree that this isn't a good way for the player to feel any slight challenge at all.
When you fall down for the weird flying platforms you get some sort of cutscenes where the so called zombies are killing you, how did they get there?
The concept is very unoriginal and I'd go as far as to say that anyone with basic knowledge of game and software development could make a game similar to this.
There appears to be a whopping 9 levels in the game.
The overall physics engine seems both floaty and static at times and it makes the game very unfun.
There are no hints in game that tell you anything about your objective or how to actually finish the level when you have killed off all the zombies.
Zombies are such an overused game concept.
The game gets very frustrating as you often fall off the face of the earth and have to start the 'test level' over again.
If this game is a finished product then why the hell would the levels be called 'Test #' anyways??

If you like unfinished and wonky piece of â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ games with overused concepts, go ahead and buy it. I feel like the 0,14â‚¬ that I paid for it was way too much for this â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥.

reviewText:
This game is good. Utterly good.

I must admit it, it's very short: there are only nine levels, and once you complete them the game is over. There are no achievement to keep you playing a little... Things like complete every level in order without dying even once.
Furthermore, the difficulty swings between excessively easy to quite hard, depending by the level and other factors.
Only three weapons, and when you can choose which you want to use, the machinegun turns out to be the best one, most efficient and the one with the best feedback. The baseball bat... it's a melee weapon, hence you'll find it having its inherent downsides, along with a low speed; Nonetheless, I found the shotgun having the same, discouraging, rate of fire.

But forget all these things! There are flaws, undoubtedly, but the bright colours and the happy dubstep soundtrack will surely let you enjoy the little trip among the twists and turns that this game has to offer. It will be a short ride, but intense and original.
While you will find yourself unable to change almost any settings, but it doesn't matter; this is a game that has to be taken as we used to approach those Insert Coin games, which entertained ourselves for several hours in the arcade rooms.

Do not expec a masterpiece. Expect something that feels not even Beta Access, but Alpha Build, regardless, I recommend you this purchase: if you're going to pay it less than a burger, then it's definitely worth the purchase!

If you need ratings

Grapich: 6
Sound: 6
Longevity: 2
Gameplay: 6

Overall: 5/10

As someone who dislikes the dubstep, I'm in love with its soundtrack. It's surprisingly fitting for this terrible game.
Buy it if you can appreciate simplistic games.

reviewText: Decent but oft frustrating game where you run around pixelated platforms and hallways smacking down bit alien zombies with baseball bats, guns (and actually that is all I have used lol). It features simple k/m controls (WASD, Space, and M1/M2). It's really that basic. However, as you advance, the platforms tend to fall away behind you, so strategic retreats become quite limited without you falling to your death. It uses a basic point health system...you have 100, the creatures tend to have more. The game actually looks pretty cool, and the gameplay such as it is works perfectly. I have encountered no bugs or the like. So, while there isnt a whole lot to this game, it is a nice distraction and for the sub twenty cent price point it often features (with trading cards that allow you to make back your investment), this is a title I expect to see in pretty much every Steam Library.\n\nThis is a 6 out of 10 for me, but for the trading card budget titles, this is actually one of the better ones out there.

reviewText:
Dead Bits is a First Person Shooter game that takes place in a very Minecraft/Roblox-like world. But is it worth buying? Here are the pros and cons of this game.

PROS:
+The music is decent
+The enemies explode in a very satisfying way
+Guns have bottomless clips
+Challenging, but not impossible

CONS:
-Slippery controls
-Enemies have no AI besides to chase you
-No checkpoints
-The credits say Game Desing" instead of "Game Design"
-The "Story"

reviewText:
This game is baffling. It's hard to understand how this got through the Greenlight program. First of all the graphics are ugly. I don't know if they were attempting a simple look with the boxy models like Minecraft, but there is no thought put into how things are modeled with the boxes or textured.

Instead of attempting to fix very simple problems like enemies being placed too close to a high ledge they can't reach and hit you on the developer just set a wall there with a pop-up message that says nice try! jump down!" Which had to be more work than simply moving the enemies to a place where they couldn't be fired upon from that vantage point.

I was almost convinced it was an illusion
date: but I genuinely think simply looking at the ground for some reason slows down your character. That's the kind of weird misunderstanding of basic long established mechanics this game gets wrong.\n\nThere are only 9 levels and most of your play time will just be spent trying to cope with the bad control and poorly mapped out levels. This game plays like something developed by someone who hasn't played a game since the Nintendo 64. That isn't bashing on the 64
recommended: I mean to literally say they forgot what a video game is since they haven't actually played one since the 90s.\n\nThe only good idea in this game is the random contrived slowmotion that makes it easier to cope with the bad shooting mechanics sometimes."
hoursPlayed: December 27, 2014
voteText: false

reviewText:
This is quite possibly the worst FPS ever made. It feels like it was made by a 12-year-old as a project to teach themselves how to program.

Cons:
- Extremely primitive block-style graphics that nonetheless manage to make the game run badly on the highest quality setting on a fairly recent laptop. The way this thing looks, it should run smoothly on the first Voodoo card.
- Extremely primitive level design which consists of irregular platforms floating in the sky. Good luck trying to circle-strafe enemies without falling to your death over and over again.
- No way to save your progress. When you die, and you will, a lot (see above point), you get to load the level again and start from the beginning. You also get to wait through annoying pauses each time this happens.
- No way to adjust anything other than three levels of graphical quality and windowed vs. fullscreen mode. Not even the controls.

Pros:
LOL there are none

Conclusion:
This is not only not worth paying for, it's not worth being paid to play.

reviewText:
It's not a horrible game, but finding it on Steam and it's retail price, that's asking for too much.

This game would have been a good few minute time killer to avoid finger tapping, but it wasn't much more than that. I'd expect to see a game such as this on Newgrounds or any other flash game site, maybe even facebook. I'll begin with a general pro/con list then detail the good and bad to each test.

Pros:
+I bought it for $0.14 while it was on the Steam sale
+It did manage to create at least two startling" scenarios
date: simply because of enemies appearing in close range with no prior warning
recommended: jump-scare if you will\n+Some levels kept a focus between platforming and shooting\n+The weapons each have unique functions: machine gun
hoursPlayed: shotgun
voteText: melee
helpfulPercent: explosive\n+Weapons are introduced individually to give you a feel for their function\n+The levels are generated exactly the same every time
votesHelpful:
so you'll know exactly where everything is/spawns if you should die or replay the level.

Cons:
-Retail price is 5 dollars
-At any point if there is a possible advantage of terrain or shortcut
votesTotal: the game finds a way of nullifying that with either flying AI or invisible walls that you may see too late\n-There is a "bloom" in the crosshair
votesFunny: but any movement
commentsCount: continuous fire
column16: or jumping does nothing to affect your accuracy. Your accuracy is always 100% no matter the condition.\n-Crouching does nothing to help you
column17: with 100% accuracy
column19: and projectiles mostly in hip range
column20: crouching doesn't provide any advantage.\n-Enemies shatter into blocks. Anything too large of a block of that enemy will usually physically impede your movements when you collide with it. This becomes irritating when strafing suddenly comes to a stop because the block is on the ground nearby.\n-Any moving platform does not physically move you. This would be fine if all the rotating platforms were all either irregular shaped or squares. This leads to the point where if you're too close to the edge
column21: the second the blocks under your feet become space
column23: typically to your death.\n-Death starts the entire level over
column24: and in most cases having prior knowledge of what's upcoming does nothing to help you progress faster simply because of the grind to kill enemies.\n-The enemy AI pathing is both good and bad. It can follow the blocks presented to make a path to you
column25: but sometimes it ignores "space" and walks over the air to reach you. They also may find themselves hung up on walls. And I mean literally as well
column26: sideways on the wall stuck.\n-Jumping has a commited jump arc. If anyone remembers the NES games of Castlevania
column27: it's like that. It is exactly like that
column28: buy a wedding ring for that jump because you're stuck with your jump direction til death do you part.\n-The game does a terrible job of explaining your environment and how it interacts with you. Several instances will lead to your death. You'll find yourself doing a trail and error with the game's environment if you see something you haven't seen before.\n-The levels are exactly the same down to enemy generation
column29: it provides no replayability.\n-The game fails to follow a flow
column30: each level is drastically different in what you just played. The only thing that follows
column32: is just reskinned enemies.\n-The slow-motion does not follow your mouse movement and just interferes with your game. If you spin the mouse to fast
column33: your character will turn back and forth between opposite directions because the mouse speed forced in slow-mo can't follow your mouse position. Red Dead Redemption and Max Payne had a function for using slow-mo as an advantage. One Finger Death Punch added slow-mo for flair
column34: but it gave you a break and prevented interfering with the game by not allowing enemies to be within reach during tha time. Dead Bits scripted slow-mo on certain enemies or cues

whether you like it or not.

-There is no pausing the game

reviewText:
Well, there's exactly what you can usually expect from a free game:
-it's short
-it has occasional bugs (like being unable to jump over to the higher platform)
-when you die you start the whole level from the very beginning
-it's quite hard - you die easly if you're not lucky enough
-in most levels you are required to just move backwards while shooting in order to kill the enemies.

I liked the music and graphics style though.

Anyway, in my opinion the whole game feels more like a demo version of the game that does not exist.

I have to say.

This game is ludicrously exceptional! The cinematics are comparable of those to, hmm, it makes me contemplate as the utter graphical surpremacy is more advanced to any other game of this time.

The story, I say, is as well thrilling, gripping, and intuitive. Follow the tragic tale of an innocent boy (I'm assuming, as he seems young and agile, Haha!) who, one peaceful evening, gets kidnapped by a dirty scoundrel by the identity of Quanton. I presume Quanton is some technologically superior being, with hovering vehicles (which by the way, look exponentially better than any sci-fi game before), countless types of minions, and numerous high quality tests, all personally for his entertainment.

This masterpiece of modern and historical culture should be many times more expensive, as a dollar can not capture this... this... perfection. The ending was, as many say, dumb" but I found it captivating. Quilly

reviewText:
This game is simply awful. Its not the graphics and its not the music, nor in a way the game itself.

Its very easy to die in this game, infact its very easy to die several times before you even actualy start the level, and thats fine however the lack of a quick restart makes this very annoying, each time you dies haveing to go through the death fmv, back to the level select and loading up the level again. Haveing to sometimes do this 2 or 3 times before even starting the level can be very frustrating, esp as the levels are getting longer and longer.

The levels are very narrow either with walls or death drop and the mobs are very large in relation to the world, the so far every level has you starting by dropping into the world being swarmed by 5+ mobs and you have no where to go but a drop death or blast through and hope you don't fall.

Weapons are odd, the guns being unlimited ammo with no reload required. The MG needing lots of bullets to kill something, the shotgun needing 2 and yet a lead pipe needing only 1 hit.

Even if you thrive on challanging games and do not mind repetition ( I don't mind replaing games or levels for chevos but this is something else ) I assure you that this game will push you over the edge, I must have spent nearly as much time playing as reloading from death.

Warning watching the game intro will result in an epileptic fit, its tantamount to sitting in a room full of strobe lights with your eyes taped open.

The soundtrack is pretty freaking awesome if you like EDM (dubstep / techno / etc).

The game is basically a blocky minecraft lookalike FPS.

You're thrown into increasingly difficult levels with a random weapon or two to choose from, left to your own devices to fight your way through the level to the exit portal.

The gameplay mechanics are very similar to oldschool shooters like DOOM in this sense. Enter level, kill stuff, exit.

My only criticism is that the cool menu music is mostly absent in game. I'd love a soundtrack to kill to.

Oh and the levels are stupidly easy to fall off and die.. but that's probably just me.

Currently it's $0.14 on the steam Xmas sale. Well worth the money, and i'm pretty sure the cards it drops are worth more than the price of the game anyway.

After much turmoil I finally beat it. I had a heartrending conversation with my lost friend, and had a bittersweet departure, never to see him again.

This game features realistic physics, such as retaining full momentum when you jump without any strafing, landmasses which require much maneuvering despite being so easy to fall as there are no railguards.

This game features a beautifuly crafted modern orchestral soundtrack by genius artists, professers of wubtronics.

It was a wild ride.

10/10

reviewText:
Alpha version simulator...

Dead Bits is a first person 3D shooter developed by Microblast games. I honestly didn't expect much going into a game with a 'mixed' User Reviews and amazingly I was surprised... the game was worster than I anticipated.

There is minimal story. Basically, you are abducted by aliens and forced to under go various 'test levels' in order to escape. No story is played before each level, so you don't really know what's really going on.

Graphics are poor. The weapon models aren't good (they just don't look right). Textures for all models (weapons, terrain, enemies) lack detail. Animations for both your guns and enemy attacks look clunky.

Gameplay is a mess. The aim of the game is to defeat all enemies and then escape via a portal at the end. In order to reach the end, you have to face off against a variety of zombies which each have unique health and speed stats. To assist you against such foes, most levels provide you with a weapon which include a bat, smg or shotgun (only 3). Weapons don't have ammo and can be fired constantly with minimum consequences. There is also a platforming element to the game which isn't well implemented due to level design issues. Basically, there are alot of holes in the platforms which basically lead to death. There are no check points in the game, so after each death you will have to watch the game over screen and start from the very beggining of the level. The result is frustration, as you have waste all that time for no progress and will have to spend more time just to get back to where you were before. There is also no snese of achievement, no reward for defeating enemies and finishing off a level which removes the drive to complete this game, making it a chore to complete rather than being fun.

Level design is atrocious. As mentioned previously, the holes in the platforms make it annoying to move around as you can easily fall to your death. A further problem is when you are rushed by a group of enemies and forced to juggle between your foes and the environment. There is little room to manouvre (making it extremely linear), making combat more challenging than it needs to be.

Music is decent. A techno track is played during the game, which fits quite well. Weapon sounds are poor and lack quality. Footstep sounds are strange as well. There is no voice acting.


If you want steam trading cards, wait for a sale to get this game. Else, stay far away.

reviewText:
Good idea (...I guess...).

Terrible implementation, horribly executed, poorly done.
No options whatsoever besides the most base of graphical tweaks, both floaty and slidy controls (not even redundant in this game's case); Dead Bits apparently demands strategy and quickwittedness to navigate the slim walkways - none can be applied, as your greatest opponent in Dead Bits will be to reckon the handling.

Sountrack is pretty good. I hate 2D/pixel art
date:
but I like what's in Dead Bits (probably because the weapons don't look half bad (dat chrome bat doe)) - the water is one of the best things (so simplistic, such nice). The slow-mo a la Killing Floor is hit-or-miss. If you've got the mouse down pat, it'll be awesome. If you feel as though excessive mouse acceleration or something is in the game while just walking, it will be one of the things that kills you most.
Speaking of the mouse, the head-bob and whatnot makes it seem as though your character moves more realistically than one would expect. Due to the weird controls, I can't dig it.

Again, good idea. Though not original, I can appreciate that an attempt was made. That's just it though - it seems not much thought was put into the actual design. I am not raging just to rage - I can only hope (I do assume) that, what with Microblast Games trying to push another project through Greenlight, they've taken to heart all the criticisms within these Mixed reviews. I would say to vote Yes on Particula and see what improvements they have made towards polishing their games, because Dead Bits isn't actually as abyssmal as some reviews (mine included) make it out to be, if you can hack it...

reviewText:
Honestly, I'd give this game a meh or a sideways thumb, but I honestly think it falls a little more under the thumbs down catagory rather than the thumbs up catagory. This game is more of a rage game than a happy, fun, shoot-em-up kid game. Even though you can tell this is definitely centered towards kids, this really isn't as fun as you'd think it is. You can tell it's towards kids because 1. Dubstep (that's it's ONLY soundtrack) 2. Simple, blocky textures 3. It's an FPS recreation of Minecraft.

Gameplay
It's exactly as you'd think- an FPS version of Minecraft. Nothing against the developers, but this type of gameplay is getting stale. I'm honestly surprised there weren't any COD weapons put in this game, considering how cliche it is.

Story
The story isn't really that original and is very forgetful. You start the game where your protagonist is sitting on his porch and is abducted by aliens and is forced to do these tasks to earn his freedom again. So basically, he just enslaved him. I say it's forgetful because damn, I really forgot I was captured by aliens while fighting off these Ice enemies shooting gigantic snow balls at me. True story, it's in level 5.

Gameplay Mechanics
The mechanics aren't exactly great in this game either. The developers chose not to go with checkpoints- which I think is a stupid idea. Without checkpoints, you are forced to restart the entire level if you die and quite frankly, dying is pretty common. Lots of the times, I'll get really far into the mission and then accidently fall off the edge of the platform I'm walking on and die, forcing me to restart the entire mission. This brings me to my next topic- enemies and how â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ing overpowered they are.

Enemy Mechanics
No matter which enemy you are fighting, 1 hit will always take away 12 HP and you only have 100 HP. The enemy AI is programmed to kill you with no cost whatsoever, and so your enemies will hunt you down until they kill you or you kill them. Killing enemies aren't hard at all, but when they stack up and you're against 3 or 4 enemies at once, they can kill you within seconds.

Frame Rates
Finally, something good I can talk about. Frame rates are very smooth and do not drop below 50 FPS. This makes things a lot smoother and more easy to play.

Conclusion
Overall, I didn't have much fun with this game. It'd be a LOT better if they fixed jumping lengths (because on level 5, I died so many times just trying to get from spawn up to the giant ice enemy), added in multiplayer (both online and local), fixed enemy damage values, and maybe changed their gameplay a bit. I hate to bash on these developers because their game isn't really that bad, they just need some fine tuning before I'd call it a full retail game. 5/10

reviewText:
This game is terrible.

Do not buy, do not play. If you have it already, then you can at least get some of your money back with the cards. I see what they were going for, an arcade shooter, but this just is not fun. Not only do the enemies tend to change speed depending on your playthrough of a particular level, but the difficulty is all over the place. Then there's the lava, another insta-kill obstacal in a setting where you can wander off the edge of the level for insta-death, or fall through a hole in the level for insta-death. No checkpoints either.

Made it to test 6" before I started thinking about "What am I willing to put up with?" Four attempts later the answer was "NOT THIS!"

The soundtrack isn't all that great
date: and the sound design doesn't do it any favors either.\nCannot recommend."

reviewText:
I got this game for free, and it is definitely worth more! You might ask, Why is this game worth my 99 cents when it looks so bad???" I have the answer for you right here.

Zombies. Dubstep. Random slow-mo effects. Graphics of a Roblox game.

The AI alone has blown me away with the fact that they actually go after you. If you go towards them
date: they walk towards you! Revolutionary!\n\nThe soundtrack has kept me around for awhile. I decided to buy the seperate soundtrack because the 1 dubstep song featured in every single level is just too good to only hear for 9 levels in a row. Check the Top 40 charts
recommended:
it should be there somewhere.

The non-stop action of this game kept me biting my nails and hanging on the edge of my seat for the 15 minutes of playtime I got! Random slow-mo effects after kills that waste your time will blow. you. away. It's as if you're immersed in the action without even needing an Oculus Rift. Truly mindblowing.

The graphics are simply beautiful. They're lego-like
hoursPlayed: and you can't get enough without longing for your childhood. You'll begin to miss the smell of your soiled undergarments by the time you're two levels in. This game rivals the graphics of the HD game
voteText: Roblox! Dead Bits truly shoves all competition aside!\n\nOverall
helpfulPercent: I would I would give this game a 5/5. I would love to see what free trading cards Microblast Games will give us in their next game!\n"
votesTotal: true

reviewText: I was actually having a pretty decent time playing Dead Bits, for a bit. While amateurish, the developer clearly had at least a basic grasp of game design, and there was a lot of variety in the challenges. It wasn't a straight-up FPS, it was sometimes a platformer, sometimes an FPS, and sometimes a hit-things-with-a-bat game". It combined all of them at certain points too
date: which I think is where it really shined.\n\nUnfortunately
recommended: I couldn't finish it. The game is rather difficult
hoursPlayed: in spite of the simplistic AI
voteText: mostly due to the challenges being laid out like an endurance gauntlet. Now
helpfulPercent: I like gauntles
votesTotal: but the stages are pretty long and there's a distinct lack of checkpoints. After retrying the sixth stage around four times
votesFunny: I just couldn't be bothered to run through again. The amateurish game design and intentionally harrowing first person platforming are tolerable and even enjoyable at first
commentsCount: but on repeat runs they become annoyances. It's a real shame
column16: too
column17: because with even a semi-generous checkpoint system
column18: I would've had a pretty good time."

reviewText: Considering the entire game was developed by one man, Dead Bits is a pretty impressive effort. Unfortunately, the game is lacking in almost every aspect when compared to its competition with the exception of its toe-tapping, head-bobbing dubstep soundtrack. If you're curious what's possible with the Unity engine and you like dubstep, it might be worth a look, and if you do, make sure to add on the soundtrack for a buck. Otherwise, stay clear.

reviewText:
This game is terrible.

Do not buy, do not play. If you have it already, then you can at least get some of your money back with the cards. I see what they were going for, an arcade shooter, but this just is not fun. Not only do the enemies tend to change speed depending on your playthrough of a particular level, but the difficulty is all over the place. Then there's the lava, another insta-kill obstacal in a setting where you can wander off the edge of the level for insta-death, or fall through a hole in the level for insta-death. No checkpoints either.

Made it to test 6" before I started thinking about "What am I willing to put up with?" Four attempts later the answer was "NOT THIS!"

The soundtrack isn't all that great
date: and the sound design doesn't do it any favors either.\nCannot recommend."

reviewText:
I don't even know where to begin. This game was boring and wasn't a good experience at all. The concept is bad and the mechanics and level design are worse.

~Level Design~
-Getting stuck on blocks
-Flung out of world
-Holes where there shouldn't be

~Pros~
+Soundtrack
+Price on Sale

~Cons~
-Movement was rugged and rough
-Level Design was â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥
-Overused concept of zombies
-â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ Story
-Most Acceleration is permantely on
-Options for very few things
-fullscreen or widescreen
-Mouse Sensitivity
-Graphics Quality
-Short Game
-The terrible controls make this game more difficult than it should be

~Verdict~
~Do Not Buy under any circumstances~

~That is All~
~Indie Reviewer Soggy Banana~

reviewText:
Dead Bits is one of those magical series of games that always cause huge amounts of excitement. It sprung onto the NES scene in 1987, and it was a runaway success. Remember the chip shortages that delayed the 1988 release of the Adventure of Dead Bits? Or what about the first time you saw pictures of the Japanese version of 1991's A Dead to the Bits? With the possible exception of Mario, no Nintendo series has caused such a level of hysteria or left behind so many great memories. Dead Bits definitely follows in the footsteps of the previous games, and the result is a game that can't be called anything other than flawless.

You begin the game as a child of the forest. But by the time you're done, you'll be a fisherman, an errand boy, the hero of time, and, yes, even a traveling mask salesman. The game is chock-full of minitasks and subgames that run alongside the main quest, saving Hyrule from Ganondorf's evil. This leads to an extreme feeling of freedom, even though a good portion of the game must be executed in a linear fashion. Stuck at the water temple? Then why not go scout around for some extra heart containers while you think about your dilemma?

The control really holds the game together. Most 3D game designers still haven't mastered the art of controlling characters in a 3D environment, but that's not the case here. Link moves beautifully, and controlling his various actions is a breeze. Essentially, your B button will always attack with the sword. The A button, however, acts as an action button, performing every non-item-related task in the game. At various times, A lets you climb, grab, dive, talk, and lots more. Three of the C buttons are used for items, any of which can be assigned to any of the three buttons. The top C button zooms in to a first-person perspective, which allows you to look around. The R shoulder button is used for blocking with the shield. The Z trigger is perhaps the most important button when it comes to dealing with enemies in the 3D realm. Hitting Z while looking at an enemy will cause you to lock on to that opponent. From there you can circle-strafe around them, hop from side to side, and always block in their direction. This is key to fighting all but the most basic of enemies and is extremely well conceived.

While there are some tough monsters, the main enemy in Dead Bits is the puzzle aspect of the game. Dead Bits forces you to think before you act, with numerous puzzles spread throughout the entire game. Some puzzles must be solved simply to exit a room, while other, larger puzzles sometimes cover an entire area. Some of the game's puzzles are totally optional, usually rewarding you with a piece of a heart container - which you'll need, but you won't have to collect every single one as long as you're quick with the Master Sword.The game's items are the usual assortment you've come to expect from a Dead Bits game. The boomerang is an invaluable tool for young Link, as is the slingshot. These weapons are mere toys for Link's adult body, however, so you'll be using the bow and the hookshot (or grappling hook) for most of the game's latter portions. Bombs, of course, come in handy no matter how old you are. The ocarina is probably the most-used item in the game. Throughout the entire game, you'll learn various tunes for the ocarina. Playing these tunes does a lot of different things, such as turning night to day, opening certain doors, calling your horse, and warping from place to place. In a world as large as Hyrule, warping is an extremely useful time-saver.

Time plays an important role throughout the game. As you proceed, time passes, and day quickly becomes night. At night, the fields of Hyrule can be a dangerous place. Time travel also comes into play, allowing you to jump seven years into the future and back again. The two times act similarly to the light and dark worlds in the SNES Dead Bits game, A Dead to the Bits. Things you do as a child will affect locations, and a few puzzles require the use of both time periods.

Graphically, Dead Bits is simply unmatched. Everything about the game just looks fantastic. You can see Death Mountain in the background of some portions of the game, complete with various smoke effects depending on what stage of the game you're in. The cinematics, which, of course, use the game engine, look absolutely spectacular, and the effects used (the time travel sequence is especially sweet looking) really give the game a spectacularly majestic look. The game's sound is also really quite amazing. Every tune in the game perfectly relates to the onscreen action. Even the songs you play on the ocarina are hummable. The sound effects are also perfect. The speech consists of mostly laughter, gasps, and battle yelps (heavy on the hi-yah!") and works very
date: very well. The game also takes your location into consideration. Dungeons and large canyons sound appropriately echoey
hoursPlayed: noises are nice and warbled.\n\nIn a way

reviewText:
The game has, indeed, been provided to me for free to be reviewed, but that does not influence my review in any way.
Go to the bottom for the TL;DR if you don't feel like reading the entire review. Dead Bits is a simplistic FPS shooter featuring a creature named Quilly who has been abducted by some aliens while he was sleeping and now has to fight for his freedom . Everything is made out of blocks, so the graphics are simple, but colorful and have lighting effects, so they look pretty nice. The games has 9 levels, each one of them coming with unique challenge, graphics and the soundtrack also differs from one level to another and changes as you progress, it takes around 2 hours to finish the whole games since the levels are kind of challenging, some might even find them hard. The level design is not poor, but very linear and you're unable to explore the surroundings, you just have to looks forward and fight the enemies until the level is over. The games doesn't have a pause menu, so there's no restart level option, I am not sure if this has been intentionally not added, but would make sense since you also don't have to reload the weapons, they have infinite ammo. These 2 things make the gameplay intense. Speaking of weapons, there are five weapons: a shotgun, a rifle, a bat like thing which looks like an icicle to me, an alien blaster an a paint gun. The soundtrack is not bad at all, I am into dubstep, but I really liked it. I highly suggest trying out the Dead Bits Soundtrack DLC, trust me, it will enhance your experience.

TL;DR : Prons and Cons + my final verdict	Pros	Cons	+ Challenging and intense gameplay, some might even find it difficult.

+ Awesome soundtrack that differs from one level to another and changes as you progress. Buying the Dead Bits Soundtrack DLC will enhance your experience even more.

+ Everything is made out of cubes, the graphic style is simple, but colorful and has lighting effects, so the graphics look pretty nice.

+ The games has 9 levels, each one of them coming with a unique challenge, graphics and the soundtrack also differs from one level to another as stated above.	- The level design is linear and does not allow the player to explore surroundings.

- It's pretty short, but the thing that the levels are challenging almost compensates it.

- Does not have a pause menu, it's true that this might have not been added on purpose to make the gameplay more intense, but adding it could certainly please a lot of people, it also has no checkpoints.
Final verdict:  7.5/10
This game is a gem for its 1 â‚¬ price, but you've probably gotten it for free :^).  Whatsoever, you should definitely give this short and simplistic FPS game a try if you have 2-3 spare hours!

reviewText:
Best 14 cents I've ever spent. Friends, do yourself a favour, most of you should have Steam trading cards in your inventory just sitting there. Sell two of them on the community market for 7 cents each. That's all it takes to get this game!

I feel like the game developer Rafael Capelini Carminatti deserves support. At first I thought that maybe he may have been one of the many greenlight devs that just want to cash in. But after playing Particula which is a 3 player co-op tower defence game that he also made. It's pretty clear that although his games appear simplistic, he understands gameplay design and is experimental with the game engine.

Dead Bits is an FPS in which you must get from start to end. If you die anywhere along the way, you have to restart from the beginning of the level. There are 9 maps. I played the first 6 with the mentality that this was going to be one of those really hard games to pass. Sure enough it seemed hard and annoying at times, but it's all doable. I'm going to assume that the annoying parts was intentional and just clever by design. Give those players who are gluttons for punishment what they want!

Then I remember taking a few months break, played level 7 then stopped for no particula reason ... pun intended. Over a year went by. After getting angry with life problems, I decided to launch Dead Bits again. Loaded up level 8. I started to remember the Dub-Step music. The awesome sound flowed into my ear canal, pumped through the veins in my head and exploded a few glial cells. It felt great!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-hHZarmkZ_I
Another thing I noticed was that all of a sudden it felt easier than what I had remembered. In fact I found the experience quite relaxing. There were even funny WTF and what do I do now moments. The entire soundtrack is unlocked at the end ... nice reward in an old-school sense. And a bit of mystery with another character popping out in the end cinematic ... a hint for a sequel maybe?

btw: (Dead Bits)Unity Game Engine !== (Minecraft)Lightweight Java Game Library
I don't understand how people can make that comparison.

reviewText:
Absolutely horrible game. I'll keep this short since this game has already wasted enough of my time; but perhaps I can prevent it wasting any of yours.

The visuals are awful, the music is horrible (even if you like dubstep, it's really bad), the handling is floaty and innacurate, the mouse control is truly abysmal, the animations are basic and janky, there's a distinct lack of content and the options are almost non-existent. Controls are not rebindable and there's no option foy inverting y-axis. Actually, there's almost no options for anything. There are only nine short levels and the nicest thing I can say about the level design is 'bland'.

Dead Bits has no redeeming features whatsoever and should be avoided like the plague. Even for free I couldn't recommend this game to anybody; there are far better free flash games on the web that are more deserving of your time than this.

Oh, and the devs are banning anybody who dares say anything bad about the game from the forums and deleting their posts. Make of that what you will.
