reviewText:
It's a pretty okay FPS game. It's not top-notch, however. Here is my review:

It's a fun and colorful first-person shooter that seems very suiting for a child, yet fun enough for a gamer such as myself to give it a shot. It has 9 unique levels with a cubic pixel art-esque design to it, full of zombies and demons and blocks (Oh, my!), which is great. It has a nice variety of three, count 'em, THREE weapons (as far as I know). It's very simple to start playing and very hard to stop until you beat it.
It also has a pretty good framerate on my 2003 Windows XP Hewlett-Packard laptop. If you like FPS games but don't have a lot of money or an insane gaming build, then consider buying this. The graphics are still great.

Now, the not-so-good part:
- The game is extremely short, not even an hour's worth of gameplay
- Level design needs serious work, as there's tons of holes in the ground
- If you're on a moving platform, Quilly (Protagonist) won't move with it, so be very careful.
- Enemies on early levels are poorly placed, seemingly spammed onto the map.
- Very repetitive gameplay
- Imperfect parkour
- Unbalanced weapon to enemy health ratio

Now the part what everyone wants to here. Is it recommended? YES and NO. But personally, I'm leaning more toward YES. The game may not be perfect, but the $1 price tag is fair enough in my opinion. And it goes on sale A LOT. The gameplay is fun nonetheless, and is challenging in certain levels (LEVEL 3, 6 AND 7). Simple controls and very great optimization so even your toaster can run the game at a solid 60 frames per second. It has parkour, kinda, which is difficult which adds to the fun of the challenge (Lv6) and the graphics are good enough for you to make out what it going on.

I rate 7/10.

Note to developer(s): I enjoyed your game thoroughly, however the one thing that got me the most was the weapon inbalance and/or the enemies' health. The shotgun is very overpowered and does not need perfect aim to take 350 HP off of an enemy. The melee weapon did a significant amount of damage at 200 HP, which is balanced with enemy's health. The machine gun only did 20 HP damage, which was very poor when it came to the enemies' health. It does somewhat remind me of Call of Duty Zombies, at around Round 12. The game clearly needs work, but you've done good so far. Keep it up ;)

reviewText:
I completed the game in 1 hour and 30 minutes and I loved it, here is why:

+ The game has 9 levels (tests) total, each one is vastly different from another. You have different monsters to kill in each one, in some you can drive a vehicle, in others you don't even have a weapon and you mostly have to parkour to complete it.
+ Another thing I like is that you don't have to reload your weapons, once you pick it up, you can press the shoot button and never let go, that makes the big areas with many mosters slightly easier than it should, but I don't mind.
+ The boss battles are very satisfying and difficult, especially the one in Test 6, that one was a doosie.
+ NO CHECKPOINTS, you will die a lot and some levels are pretty lengthy, having no checkpoints makes the game much more difficult that it normally would be. I like that, saving anywhere you want is not to my liking, especially in a game like this. Sometimes it could be very frustrating ofcourse, but you can always replay the level.
+ Tha graphics are nothing special, but I love the art style, punching a wall and seeing all the bits and pieces of it fly in random directions is very satisfying.
============
The game has many flaws aswell:

- Jumping is weird and very floaty, you don't know where you are going to land and sometimes you can't move mid-air.
- Walking feels a bit weird too and also floaty, in some instances you can walk over a one block wide gap, in others you can't. This is very apparent in Test 6.
- There is no A.I. whatsoever, the monsters just run at you and if they get stuck behind a wall, they will stay there and you can shoot at them until they die. Sometimes they even fall from the world if there is a gap between you and them.
=============
Final words:
I really liked the game. I got it for 14 cents with a 97% discount and already got my money back by selling trading cards, the game is worth so much more than that and I recomment it to everyone, once you get used to the jumpind mechanics, you will like it. It took me 15 minutes to see the appeal of it.

reviewText:
I've never done LSD, but I imagine it would feel kind of like playing this game.

Honestly this game is pretty terrible. The combat is simplistic, repetitive, and tedious; the physics and platforming are wonky and unpredictable; the graphics are often hideous and/or epilepsy inducing; the difficulty ranges from stupidly easy to rage inducingly hard; and what little story there is seems kind of like the ravings of a mad man and feels somewhat unnecessary. But for some reason it kept me playing to the end. Sure it was incredibly frustrating, and I had already gotten all the card drops (enough to more than make up for the cost of the game, the main reason I even bought and played this), but something just compelled me to press forward and beat this game. I just wanted to show it who's boss. And I did. All in all I beat the game in about 2 and a half hours, including the wholly unnecessary post-credits cutscene in which you watch the protaganist sleeping for what feels like a full minute and a half as nothing happens (other than a brief one second glimpse of some strange duck-like creature that seems to be spying on our hero with no explanation).

Get this game if you want free money, keep playing if you like dubstep made by aliens and getting ticked off when your character randomly spazzes out and throws himself off a cliff.

reviewText:
TL;DR at the end!

Where many people have stated that this is one of the worst games ever, I disagree. While not necessarily being a 'good' game, it's something that I would recommend for the current sale price, 14 cents, however, would advise against purchasing if not $1 or under.

The game features 9 levels of increasing difficulty, many which explores various playing styles, including shooting, parkour (think jumping challenges) and vehicle combat. While all of these things are touched upon a very basic level, it keeps your limited experience with the game interesting.

Where other's have noted that the maneuverability of the character is difficult and poorly designed, I have not found this to be a problem for myself. However, the AI is very simplistic, but it's arguable that the simplicity of the characters match that of the overall style of the game itself.

The visual design of the game is clearly not very in-depth with 95% of the games assets being made up of cubes and solid colours. At times, the level design is questionable with many sections seeming unnecessary, such as platforms leading to nowhere. The theme of the game varies along the levels from encountering zombies with traditional weaponry (rifle/shotgun) to some sort of laser weapon where you fight UFO's (and eventually get to control one).

The overall sounds of the game are very basic, I wouldn't be surprised if they were from free-sounds, however, the dubstep-y style of music is quite interesting and often suits the tempo of play. If you're into more techno style of music, you might enjoy this.

One of the few qualms that I have the this game is that of the UI. In the game, there are no labels for each element. For instance, I wasn't aware that the numbers on the bottom of the screen was my health indicator until the third level. Pressing escape brings up a 'pause' UI, with settings and menu buttons, however, it doesn't actually pause the game; enemies will still attack you and you can still move your character. Another issue which I had with the game was the occasional frame rate drop when many elements on screen (with a GTX 760), which as times would cause me to miss a jump.

TL;DR:  In all, I would recommend this game on sale, not the full price of $5 (at the time of writing). It's a nice casual game which will take you around 40 mins to complete the 9 levels it has in full. It's a perfect game to play if you're waiting for something else to download. On sale, you could make your money back from cards. Some UI and stability issues are present, but not that bad.

reviewText:
This is a very bad games in many aspects.
The level design is very poor, ranging from corridor/tube to empty, weird shaped platforms suspended on instadeath pits. They might as well just made it on rails: there is no exploration, there are no multiple ways to progress, just hold the fire button and hope you kill something.
The weapons are laughable, in variety and aesthethics and feel. It's not a satisfactory shooting experience, the very few weapons are boring and have no impact behind them.
The game is hideous. The stretched textures on the spawning platform deserve a honorable mention.

The game is frustrating, because it sets up cheap deaths. The corridor falls behind you, it forces you to fight on narrow platforms, it doesn't let you choose where and how to engage enemies.
I still don't understand the point of the score system, since you pretty much have one way and one way only to complete the  levels, and there is no timer.

reviewText:
Horrid. Absolutely not worth a cent.

Mouse acceleration. Floaty controls. Enemy animations (what are they, dancing before you walk right in front of them, as if they don't see you?). The only good thing about this is the graphic style. The physics engine is terrible, and performance drops whenever there are more than 20-30 physical elements for it to calculate.

Also, my god, the soundtrack. Dubstep? Seriously?

The menus are simplistic, though passable. The lack of a choice of resolution or individual graphics quality options is absolutely unforgivable, as is the lack of key rebinding. Also, did I mention mouse accel?

Also for some reason each stage requires that you press your Return key before it actually starts, as if the programmer couldn't just run the level from the start. This wastes 5-10 seconds each time you load a level. And since in the later levels you die a lot, that's a TON of time wasted.

Bottom line: don't get it. And in the off chance you get it for free, DON'T WASTE YOUR TIME ON IT LIKE I DID.
It's not worth it.

reviewText: Pretty boring, it's just a mediocre FPS with nothing much to it, it has 3 weapons and like 5 enemies, the levels are just not fun to go through, some are pretty long and are just a bunch of long corridors with no checkpoints in it, so if you die for any dumb reason you've got to star the boring level all over again, making them even more boring. There are also plataform sections, even though the jumping sucks, you can't control it at all in mid air and you jump very slowly, you expect to be able to go the same speed horizontaly jumping as you go walking, but that's not the case, while jumping you just move slowly, making the plataforming very awkward. Besides, the graphics just don't do their job, in the fire level for example, you can't touch the stationary orange blocks because they are supposed to be lava, and yet later in the level there are some orange plataforms that you're required to go through to advance, nevermind the fact that right before those blocks there was a hekf wall of orange blocks that you die if you touch, there's simplistic, and then there's just lazy, the graphics in this game are just lazy, I don't mind simple looking games, but the graphics have to at least do their job of diplaying what's on screen.

reviewText:
Average indie title, but at moments can become fun and ecstatic, where you run around pixelated platforms and hallways destroying zombies in your way with guns and melee weapons.

The game is really basic for the most part but as you start to advance through the levels various gameplay mechanics are implemented to increase the difficulty of retreating.

The game is fun to play, and seems to be bug-free for the most part. Through trading cards you are able to make back your investment and then some due to the very low price point of around $0.20, it is a nice game to play for a few hours and I would reccomend you pick this up as.. it's a game.. which you can make easy profit from?

TL;DR: Basic yet fun game. 7/10

reviewText:
I really do hope the developers will update the game but somehow I doubt it.

Anyways, as I am writing this review, this game is in a realy bad condition. The game feels unfinished. And that's the biggest and only problem this game has.

The idea of the game is kinda fun. I've always liked physics based games and just stuff that can be blown up with weapons. I really loved the look of the game and watched the trailer saying to myself: Wow! This has to be one of the coolest games released lately and it's only 4.99â‚¬!". Although I payed 0.99â‚¬ for this.

reviewText:
This game needs improvement. My opinion MIGHT change if these problems are solved.
Music 9/10
Gameplay 6/10
Story 4/10
Like someone said earlier Test 6 is literally impossible, sure there is a health pack and all but aiming upwards is out of the question. No double jump?? WHAT this is ridiculous it's impossible to try and not fall off into oblivion. And why the sharp turns and edges?! I have found myself falling off more than a hundred times and I'm sick of it! I can't fully understand the ending or what the final test it because I CANNOT get past level 6. And I REFUSE to continue wasting my life on this game. I would get some profit from the game gaining a few cents more but that's IT. In conclusion, for 19 cents it's OK. I suggest not buying it when it's not less than 99 cents.

reviewText:
This game is the perfect sequel to Year 2066. It has a complex and intricate gameplay, featuring futuristic weapons with increadible physics.
I would recommend buying this game if you like:
-Call of the Duty
-The forementioned Year 2066
-Tetris.
-Slowmotion and dubstep
-To see yourself â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ and eaten alive by grey zombies
I would not recommend buying this if:
-You want to change the settings (the game is not intended to support advanced technology such as changing graphics quality)
-You are not a veteran at fps. This game is really difficult to beat (I couldn't beat Test 4")
-You are not mlg

reviewText:
Disclaimer: I was effectively paid to play this game. I bought this game on sale which it is frequently on and then after a short period of playing, making coffee and toast, and petting the dog, I sold the trading cards for more than the price I paid originally. However, I will not allow this to unbias my review.
Dead Bits: a Bit of a Hidden Gem?Pros:
+ Moments where you actually feel like one cool bad apple!
+ Wub Wub Wub

Cons:
- FOR A DUB STEP GAME WITH AWESOME SOUNDTRACK WHY IS IT ALWAYS DAMN TOO SILENT!!
- No Jetpack
- No Infinite loop spawn of monsters and wub wub wub horde style mode.

Conclusion: Come for the trading cards, stay for the wub. Regardless if you buy this game on sale or not, Dead Bits is still a fun way to kill an hour. It is a shame with a little more polish and tought. this game could have really been something much much more. A BBB game.

Bad Joke To Really Conclude (for those who have played): Glados would approve of this game, every level you play is a test.

reviewText:
Horrid. Absolutely not worth a cent.

Mouse acceleration. Floaty controls. Enemy animations (what are they, dancing before you walk right in front of them, as if they don't see you?). The only good thing about this is the graphic style. The physics engine is terrible, and performance drops whenever there are more than 20-30 physical elements for it to calculate.

Also, my god, the soundtrack. Dubstep? Seriously?

The menus are simplistic, though passable. The lack of a choice of resolution or individual graphics quality options is absolutely unforgivable, as is the lack of key rebinding. Also, did I mention mouse accel?

Also for some reason each stage requires that you press your Return key before it actually starts, as if the programmer couldn't just run the level from the start. This wastes 5-10 seconds each time you load a level. And since in the later levels you die a lot, that's a TON of time wasted.

Bottom line: don't get it. And in the off chance you get it for free, DON'T WASTE YOUR TIME ON IT LIKE I DID.
It's not worth it.

reviewText:
Average indie title, but at moments can become fun and ecstatic, where you run around pixelated platforms and hallways destroying zombies in your way with guns and melee weapons.

The game is really basic for the most part but as you start to advance through the levels various gameplay mechanics are implemented to increase the difficulty of retreating.

The game is fun to play, and seems to be bug-free for the most part. Through trading cards you are able to make back your investment and then some due to the very low price point of around $0.20, it is a nice game to play for a few hours and I would reccomend you pick this up as.. it's a game.. which you can make easy profit from?

TL;DR: Basic yet fun game. 7/10

reviewText:
This is what Bubsy 3D would have been if it was an FPS.

Dead Bits is about a block guy who gets kidnapped by aliens. In order to escape, he must go through 9 of the alien leader's tests. The game is just a generic FPS where you shoot at random enemies until they die. Enemies are slower than you and you never have to reload, so all you need to do is run away and shoot. No effort required.

Despite the combat being incredibly easy, the game still has ways of making itself difficult. For starters, the game will go into a black and white slow-mo effect at random when you shoot at enemies. This feature is as annoying as it sounds, and gets old immediately after the first time its used (and no, it can not be turned off). For a few levels, you need to kill every enemy to unlock the next level. So if you're at the end of a level but forgot just one enemy, you'll have to go all the way back.

On top of this, jumping is really awkward. Whenever you jump, you are basically locked into that animation, so if you stand still and jump, you will always go straight up even if you try to move in the air. In a regular FPS, this wouldn't be that much of a problem, but in one that relies heavily on platforming such as Dead Bits, it often leads to many accidental deaths. Also if you die, you always get kicked back to the level select screen.

The visuals do not bring the game any justice either. The game is composed entirely of blocks, making the game look like some crappy Minecraft mod. The music is just generic dubstep, supposedly to give you that cool and hip 420 blaze it" feel that the kids are into nowadays. Everything in the game from the text to how you start each level in mid-air feels like some sort of mod and lacks any polish (the button you click on the menu to go into level select is always titled "new game;" think about that for a second).

Yes
date: I am aware that this game was apparently made by one person. I can get past the graphics and the music
recommended: but the monotonous gameplay and other faults are what keeps this game from being a decent experience. If you really want to try it out
hoursPlayed: it's only $1 so knock yourself out. Otherwise
voteText: save your precious dollar for something better."

reviewText:
Disclaimer: I was effectively paid to play this game. I bought this game on sale which it is frequently on and then after a short period of playing, making coffee and toast, and petting the dog, I sold the trading cards for more than the price I paid originally. However, I will not allow this to unbias my review.
Dead Bits: a Bit of a Hidden Gem?Pros:
+ Moments where you actually feel like one cool bad apple!
+ Wub Wub Wub

Cons:
- FOR A DUB STEP GAME WITH AWESOME SOUNDTRACK WHY IS IT ALWAYS DAMN TOO SILENT!!
- No Jetpack
- No Infinite loop spawn of monsters and wub wub wub horde style mode.

Conclusion: Come for the trading cards, stay for the wub. Regardless if you buy this game on sale or not, Dead Bits is still a fun way to kill an hour. It is a shame with a little more polish and tought. this game could have really been something much much more. A BBB game.

Bad Joke To Really Conclude (for those who have played): Glados would approve of this game, every level you play is a test.

reviewText:
This is what Bubsy 3D would have been if it was an FPS.

Dead Bits is about a block guy who gets kidnapped by aliens. In order to escape, he must go through 9 of the alien leader's tests. The game is just a generic FPS where you shoot at random enemies until they die. Enemies are slower than you and you never have to reload, so all you need to do is run away and shoot. No effort required.

Despite the combat being incredibly easy, the game still has ways of making itself difficult. For starters, the game will go into a black and white slow-mo effect at random when you shoot at enemies. This feature is as annoying as it sounds, and gets old immediately after the first time its used (and no, it can not be turned off). For a few levels, you need to kill every enemy to unlock the next level. So if you're at the end of a level but forgot just one enemy, you'll have to go all the way back.

On top of this, jumping is really awkward. Whenever you jump, you are basically locked into that animation, so if you stand still and jump, you will always go straight up even if you try to move in the air. In a regular FPS, this wouldn't be that much of a problem, but in one that relies heavily on platforming such as Dead Bits, it often leads to many accidental deaths. Also if you die, you always get kicked back to the level select screen.

The visuals do not bring the game any justice either. The game is composed entirely of blocks, making the game look like some crappy Minecraft mod. The music is just generic dubstep, supposedly to give you that cool and hip 420 blaze it" feel that the kids are into nowadays. Everything in the game from the text to how you start each level in mid-air feels like some sort of mod and lacks any polish (the button you click on the menu to go into level select is always titled "new game;" think about that for a second).

Yes
date: I am aware that this game was apparently made by one person. I can get past the graphics and the music
recommended: but the monotonous gameplay and other faults are what keeps this game from being a decent experience. If you really want to try it out
hoursPlayed: it's only $1 so knock yourself out. Otherwise
voteText: save your precious dollar for something better."

reviewText:
Average indie title, but at moments can become fun and ecstatic, where you run around pixelated platforms and hallways destroying zombies in your way with guns and melee weapons.

The game is really basic for the most part but as you start to advance through the levels various gameplay mechanics are implemented to increase the difficulty of retreating.

The game is fun to play, and seems to be bug-free for the most part. Through trading cards you are able to make back your investment and then some due to the very low price point of around $0.20, it is a nice game to play for a few hours and I would reccomend you pick this up as.. it's a game.. which you can make easy profit from?

TL;DR: Basic yet fun game. 7/10

reviewText:
I got this game on sale for pretty cheap, so naturally I expected very little from it. To be honest, I bought the game for the card drops hoping to make a little bit of profit. List of pros and cons about the game is pretty short, but:

Pros:
- The soundtrack was pretty good
- It had the right idea for the game
- Paid 27 cents for it, sold cards for 39 cents (praise foil)

Cons:
- Very kiddy block like graphics
- Super easy to beat (no actual challenge, hardest part was running through a level with no weapon to live.)
- The. â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥. LAVA.

Overall, this game served its purpose and at full price would still be worth it. If you wanna spend a dollar (I think) to waste a little over an hour of your time then this game is for you.

Finally, 7/10 would jump around brickworlds again.
